/vrpg/ is a place to discuss all types of role-playing video games, including single-player, multi-player, and massively multi-player, turn-based and real-time action, western-style and JRPG.

Does this mean RPGs are banned on other video game boards? No! /vrpg/ is just a separate board specifically focused on RPGs where discussions about your favorite games can thrive.

Please familiarize yourself with the rules and remember to use the spoiler function where appropriate!

Please note that, like /v/, "Generals"—long-term, one-after-the-other, recurring threads about a specific game are not permitted on /vrpg/. Such threads belong on >>>/vg/.

threads.com: Hommlet really doesn't seem as bad as people make it out to be.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
I thought this floor was a pretty good example of why ToEE is a good game, why 3.5e can be very tactical and interesting with good encounter design, why party composition is important, and why a good CRPG writes its own story, so I figure its worth making a post about.

Firstly, we emerge into the room and hear zombies chowing down on a hapless adventurer to the west. After scouting out the area with our rogue in stealth it becomes apparent that there is quite a few enemies to deal with, so our wizard lays down grease and I position our fighter to intercept with AoO. Slimes drop down on our heads and assault the backline, but thanks to grease the fighter is able to double back and assist the cleric in peeling them off our wizard and bard, then handily returns to the hallway to cleave down the zombies. Pretty standard stuff so far.

Next we find a hidden room to the south thanks to our rogue's skills and are ambushed by ghouls. They jump us as soon as we enter the room so I have the cleric pop Turn Undead here, as we aren't properly positioned and getting paralyzed would be potentially devastating. This allows us to make quick work of the ghouls. At the end of the room is a heap of treasure, mostly potions.

(cont.)

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2851333
Now things really get interesting. Back on the main floor we have a tiny room to the east, but we can't see inside because the door is closed. I have the cleric burst through the door as he is the tankiest and his movement is also the lowest, so he'll need all the help he can get to make use of the first turn while our enemies are flatflooted and deal with what's inside. We find an ogre. Ogres are quite dangerous at this point as their swings are virtually unavoidable and will kill us instantly, very bad news. First I bring in the wizard. He already used up his cast of grease and only has CC spells slotted that are far too weak to affect a brute of this size, so I position him in the corner to get a hit in with his sling. This is important to do first as ranged attacks recieve a -4 penalty if the target is engaged in melee. Next I position the rogue behind the ogre and get a sneak attack in, followed by the fighter and the cleric. The bard then finishes the turn by using fascinate, which the ogre immediately breaks, but this grants us a free turn. I move the bard all the way back up to the start of the turn order so he can go again immediately, this time casting grease and tripping the ogre. The rogue gets another sneak attack in, and our cleric and fighter get some good chunky hits in as well. The ogre gets up, but as he does all three of our melee get free attacks of opportunity in, finally putting him down for good and granting us enough experience to hit level 3 and ending this floor. This tiny floor in a beginner dungeon let us use all our party's unique abilities to navigate and survive it with some very simple but solid encounter design.

There really isn't a lot of RPGs that have this level of depth and interactivity. This is sort of what I wish the Pathfinder games were like as the tools to do this are there, but you're mostly just insta-gibbing stuff like its an IE game and other troika games certainly don't have good combat. Oh well.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.sub: Quickest legit way to become rich in Skyrim?
threads.com:
So, the fastest way I found was through enchanting.
I get some gold in the beginning from easy quests, then I buy a weapon with turn undead enchant or absorb health so I can disenchant it.
Then I buy the cheapest soul gems and craft some iron daggers and can sell the enchanted daggers for a profit (not big but can keep the buying/selling cycle going).

Once I have enough gold (around 7k) I power level to around level 25 (easy to do by spamming muffle, soul trap, etc...) and start shopping for the banish enchantment, the most expensive enchant in the entire game. After that, a single iron dagger enchanted with banish can easily sell for over 1K gold. You can now buy raw materials and sell the final product for a huge profit.

I'd say enchanting is the best skill tree in the game.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
A controversial one incoming -
I think that Neera is a very good example of a properly designed cRPG character. There, I said it. BG1 ONLY!

I hate Beamdog and all the butchery they did to original BG1, BG2 & IWD but amongst the rare good things they added, I think that Neera was one of them. Here's my reasoning

>the amount banter & screen time that she gets is just right
modern RPGs are far too character focused IMO, with a bunch of shit dialogue and meaningless walls of texts in general (Pathfinder, for example) and original BG1 was lacking a bit more banter between the characters & dialogue with charname. I feel like Neera strikes a fine line between those two extremes. She doesn't talk much, but isn't a complete silent mule either.

>her personality
I find her personality non exaggerated and believable. I can imagine her being.. a person. She bitches a lot and can be annoying (which is a good design choice because shes a woman) and yearns for a normal life and freedom, which is also very natural given her backstory. Way way more believable and interesting than any crap Owlcat wrote up in Pathfinder, for example.

>her quest
It was serviceable. Worked well with the character & her background, didn't bite more than it could chew, was decently challenging.

>complains about wild mages being too strong
uhhh no
if you are a number crunching munchkin, there are way more overpowered bullshit things in the game than some wild magic perks so, no.

threads.sub: Have you ever fallen in love with a vidya character?
threads.com:
Aerie has been the only one I've ever fallen in love with. She's perfect on the inside and outside. But ever since losing her wings she struggles to see beauty in herself and the world below.

On one hand it has motivated me to become the man I want to be. I began lifting for her, eating healthy, quitting porn, being productive, etc.

But ultimately this has caused me some emotional pain. I've only had one (short-lived) relationship with a girl when I was 15. At 22 I'm still kissless. I feel so miserable that I'll never find a woman like her and am afraid I'll be alone forever.

Sometimes I fall asleep listening to her romance dialogue while cry a little bit, wishing I could hold her.

Disgaea was in a weird but good place. It's a series made by someone trying to get all SRPG mechanics during SRPG boom in one place and it somehow worked out. Added with good writing and Harada's artwork.
Now good writing is gone for awhile. People don't really care about new characters that much as for any 1-4 ones. NIS tried to recapture here and there but failed, miserably so. Story itself usually nothing to write home about either, and with 6 it was badly delivered too.
Idea of mixing all SRPG mechanics slowly has been replaced with "it's all about numbers!!!" mentality. However slowly it begun to be all about "QoL" of increasing numbers from the get go and now with autobattle so you don't even need to play the game.
Stage design been unremarkable for awhile, but 6 took a cake of it being completely disgustingly bad.
Amount of content games have decreased dramatically right after 4 too.
Basically NIS lost the idea why original few games were relatevily popular, and took internet's stereotype about "numbers" and "grindan game" to the heart.

Art wise, while people still like Harada, and it's still signature look, it became a bit too polished I'd personally argue, and in age of anime girls being more plentiful than anything else on internet and entertainment, make that additional polished look not as attractive as older game series.

Now it's just another anime game whatever than can mean.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Daggerfall requires a lot of effort on the player to enjoy. A lot of suspension of disbelief. But if you allow yourself to be fooled, it is actually a very fun game. Even though every quest and city is procedurally generated, after you've been playing for a while you kind of allow the illusion that every location is unique to grow on you. You get a sense of scale and realism that no other RPG offers.

I remember Zaric saying that every region in Daggerfall felt unique to him. I thought this was nonsense. How could a region feel unique when it uses the exact same generation algorithm as every other generic region in the game? I didn't understand this until I properly played Daggerfall and gave it a chance rather than dismissing it as procedurally generated garbage like I had done before. For example, over time you remember certain town layouts, you find a city with all the right services that your character requires in the one place, or you grow fond of a city that you've done a lot of quests in. And after a while of helping people out you see your reputation in a region has grown, it feels good that your actions in this world actually mean something.

Daggerfall definitely has something that no other RPG I've played has. A sense of immersion that you really are just an itinerant adventurer living in a fantasy world. Even though it's from 1996 it feels surprisingly modern in the amount of freedom it gives you.

Of course, the Unity version and shit ton of mods help a lot too. There are a lot of quest and world overhaul mods so the game doesn't feel so samey all the time.

I didn't find the characters as compelling or enjoyable as I did EarthBound, nostalgia goggles be damned. I never played the first game, and probably won't unless there is a remake so I can test the original and remake against one another.

Mother 3 felt like it tried too hard with some comedic or quirky aspects, whereas Mother 2/EarthBound was just more relatable. Boy gets visit from aliens, obnoxious fat neighbor aptly named PORKY snarfs it all up and becomes the big bad. You meet a sweet girl in a crazy town, a nerdy boy with his gadgets, and a martial artist who eventually transcends to become his full self. Magicant and all of that was awesome too. It felt like a lot of love was put into EarthBound, and I think it shows.

Mother 3 had good gameplay and mechanics, but the story and structure, and especially the characters, were lacking. If they had an actual 4th character instead of the dog, or a stronger, more compelling protagonist, then I think it would have fared better.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
What exactly is the good part of this game? I was told it was supposed to be good, but I'm not sure I've ever felt more insulted by a game. It's designed so poorly in so many ways.

- Hardly any control over party members
- Combat is mostly just mashing the attack button, whether you are using links or not
- Battles with random mobs are never interesting. Too easy and just there to be in the way
- Only battles with any difficulty are forced solo battles which make the game even more barebones, and even those are scarce
- Feels like 1/3 of the "bosses" are forced losses where you randomly get one-shotted by volty
- Most of the 177 characters are unappealing peasants no one would ever want to play as, reducing the potential depth of the better ones (like Chrono Cross, but worse)
- To customize your party you have to do inane tasks wandering around town for the first 20 hours until you figure out how to get the one you want, if you even manage it. This is most of the game's "gameplay"
- The character you like may be level 5 when recruited 20 hours into the game, or be irredeemably bad in another way
- You can't even use the characters you like in most story battles or even any battles if you pick the wrong path, completely missing the point of having party customization
- Irredeemable bland dungeons with literal corridors that lead to nothing
- No escape rope or warp without running to a pig statue
- Stupid time system that meshes poorly with surprise story triggers
- Item limit with no storage except the jukebox

This doesn't even get into the story which is a dumpster fire in its own way. The only thing that's OK is the music, and even that has an asterisk, because it's never been more obvious that the programmer placed the music and not the composer. The audio balance is poor, with the BGM drowning out the VA. The choice of where to place music also sometimes feels unfitting, for example in cutscenes or a few dungeons (also awkward use of sitcom SFX in cutscenes.)

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.sub: What is the correct mindset to enjoy DRPGs?
threads.com:
I've tried playing some DRPGs and there's a lot of things I like about them:
>party management
>free character creation, allowing for a multitude of approaches
>first person exploration is usually immersive
>I like drawing maps and making my own notes

Even though I like all these things, there's one thing that always filters me in these games: the combat. No matter how much I try, it seems that all the DRPGs really on two types of battles: the ones where you mash attack until the enemy is dead without worrying about anything and the ones where you try to mash attack to win but the enemy completely destroys your whole party with just one attack. This second option usually becomes a RNG fest, because while the enemy always has this attack that wipes your party, it can use it on turn 1, turn 10 or never use it, so it all comes down to luck.
So, what you do to enjoy this? Do you just accept that combat is shit and decide to have a good time with the remaining characteristics of the game?

>there is no reason AC can't be merged with the DT in the way you're describing it.
Well to continue with the tank armor analogy, a tank shell can be large enough where it SHOULD be able to penetrate another tank's armor but if it hits it at a bad angle it will just deflect right off. This can be up to effectively what amounts to random chance at times, which sort of makes it more like AC (which tends to be a feast or famine random dice roll) instead of DR/DT which are flat, consistent reductions. Like the later crusader greathelms that have round tops rather than flat in picrel here aren't really "stronger" armor but they are less likely to be penetrated from an overhead blow than the older flattop ones are. You still CAN penetrate it from above, but you would need to get more lucky/accurate with the angle of your blow to do it which meshes well with the concept of AC in general.

>>2849316
I haven't tried 8 on 3DS but yeah, they censored outfits and one scene (the scene isn't even sexual). Apparently CERO has gotten stricter. They also added content but it all seems unnecessary to me and seems to throw game balance off. Though maybe kinda neat if you're replaying the game instead of playing it for the first time.

I like the ps1 version more because I think the 3DS version streamlines too much. The first hours of DQ7 were famous for not having battles - you just walked around and talked to people on the starting island and solved puzzles. This was cut down to be shorter on 3DS. I like the original intro, but if that was the only thing they changed I could live with it. But I don't like the mechanical changes either. They reworked the job system to be simpler. Previously, you could learn hybrid skills by leveling one class, then another. But since there wasn't much of an indication of what lead to what, people would miss out on certain skills that were very useful. Instead now each job has it's own discrete set of skills, with certain jobs getting more skills than they did before. The job switching feels kinda pointless, with you relearning skills and spells you learned before.
You get a map for each dungeon automatically in the 3DS version when there was no map at all for the previous game. The dungeon floor plans aren't complex so if you do this and remove random battles (which they did on 3DS), there's no tension or challenge in a dungeon at all. The on-field encounters sometimes end up being unavoidable too, which somehow feels cheaper to me than random battles.

They also removed puzzles from multiple dungeons, not just the opening. They made it easier to find fragments, which is understandable, but overall the game just feels dumbed down.

The localization is much clearer now and the graphics are very nice though. So if you want a pretty way to play through some episodic DQ stories (which are quite good) than it's not a bad option.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com: Besides extending the development cycle and increasing playtesting, what is the best way to accomodate a deep progression system without sacrificing tactical depth in the combat of a turn based JRPG?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2847810
...good planning?

I've sometimes played with the idea that RPGs could as part of their design define "limits", such that you'd calculate the optimal and minimal damage or stat when implementing a new piece of equipment or skill.

Of course, that might prevent some fun combinations, and it might become a bit hard to compute eventually if you have very complex systems.

You could even graph that stuff and see what kind of and shape of distributions you end up with. Those shapes can tell a lot.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Math, specifically, in terms of planning ahead. You can look up the "experience curve" for most games, or just plot out the experience points needed per level. The steeper it is, the longer you stay at that level assuming the experience gain is the same. If it's not, you want to then calculate something like XP per level over the amount of average XP gained from a battle/quest/item at that level. This curve helps you visualize how the game will "flow".

If your curve steeply increases, then the progression will feel like it slows down a lot. If the curve steeply decreases, then the game will feel like it gets way easier to progress as time goes on. If it's flat, then the progress will feel like it is relatively static the whole game.

In my experience, the best "progression" is time-based, so take the previous curve I mentioned and then ask "how much time on average does the player spend on each level?" If you aren't seeing tangible progress every average play-session, then the game probably feels really slow. So usually, I'd suggest making sure the player makes minor progress every ten minutes, and maybe makes "major" progress every half hour to an hour. Minor progress might be a level-up, getting a new piece of equipment, or simply reaching a new floor in a dungeon. Major progress might be getting a new major ability, completing a quest and getting multiple rewards, or finishing a dungeon.

You can always break away from the above, but it should be done so intentionally. If you random dungeon to retrieve some B-Plot item slows the game way down, you've screwed up. If your big climactic dungeon takes less time to finish and get the special Ultimate Weapon of Awesome than anything else, you've screwed up.

The QA/testing process should only be for making small tweaks. You don't want to just throw stuff at the wall and see what sticks, which means using a mathematical approach.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2848376
> The QA/testing process should only be for making small tweaks
Do you mean QA the way it is usually in software development, i.e. the last testing done at all (by "customer" or perhaps product owner)? If so, yeah, I agree.

I'd like to point out that games should have user testing done throughout the development cycle, though, which is a point that I feel doesn't come across from what you've written. I feel they're different from most software when it comes to what kind of testing they need.

FFIV is a game where you fully play through a linear script in every possible sense, you have no say about who gets to be in your party and who doesn't, at any point in the game, you can't choose how characters develop through the game, you can't even choose where to go because the game is focused on cinematic storytelling so you're not allowed to go anywhere the story doesn't allow you to go, at best you can backtrack to Baron to get Odin, which outside of being narratively inconsistent doesn't really add anything to the game.

It's still an extremely poorly made game.
Though to be fair FF as a whole is a poorly made series, IV is just one of the more blatant examples of that, together with VI, the PS1 games and XIII, it's not a series for people who like RPGs, it's something for people who just want to watch a show with some mild degree of interactivity to pretend they play games.

I think most people consider localization teams as developers. They do more than just translations.
Understandably, while they are doing their own quality assurance testing they're bound to discover a bug or something that has nothing to do with a translation.

The exception might be with software like RPG Maker. The translators work with the publishers, not the developers. They find bugs all the time, but the programmers who'd fix it are/were subcontractors that aren't going to lift a finger unless they're paid to. In that sense, RPG Maker is a child raised by a nanny and a community of neighbors, because the parent is irresponsible and neglectful.
